narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned levantine arabic and cultural/regional differences in vocabulary and phrases
I learned Levantine Arabic conversational skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The classroom environment is really engaging and you learn a lot about the dialect and cultural nuances. 
On the other hand, grading is unclear--no feedback is provided on tests, so you don't always understand why you received a certain grade or what you can improve on in the future to avoid that grade. Additionally, sometimes there would be assignments due that were not explicitly mentioned on the schedule. I think the schedule is a really useful resource for students, so it would be a good idea to update it each time there is a change/addition of an assignment. Lastly, deadlines for submitting assignments are kind of weird--on two days of the week, you have to submit your work midday, while you have to submit your work by midnight on the other days. Since we have daily assignments, I think that all homework should be due at midnight each time. It just makes scheduling/getting work done more manageable to have a consistent daily deadline.
I think in-person teaching would greatly improve this course, as virtual language use is much more difficult and less engaging.
The course is good but I felt like we needed to be challenged a bit more, for example no english in class (which I feel like was often to explain things but should have been in arabic)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I appreciated how the instructor worked to make the class engaging. We would converse in break-out rooms multiple times during each class, which was good practice.
That being said, sometimes such work felt rather repetitive; you would converse with one classmate, go to another break-out room and discuss the same thing, and then go to the main room to discuss the same thing as a class. It might be worthwhile to change topics that are being discussed to make sure that students are challenging themselves to use new sentence structures and vocabulary.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is a useful class to take and you learn so much.
I enjoyed this course, so I think someone advancing in Arabic would enjoy this course, so I might.
Yes, if you want to maintain a working knowledge of arabic.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
